Graphical abstract Practically the traditional plasticizers are produced via homogeneous esterification reaction in millions of tons annually as additives for modulating the properties of polymeric materials, facing great environment pressure such as a huge amount of wastewater produced to remove the detrimental metal catalyst. In this work, a series of MOFs, MIL-101, MIL-125, MIL-125-NH2, UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, and UiO-66-SO3H, have been synthesized and employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the syntheses of plasticizers. MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 were found to show the superior catalytic efficiency compared with other MOFs. Catalyzed by only 1.0 mol% of MIL-125 within 1.0 h at 190 °C, the heterogeneous reaction achieved 99.9 % yield of Di-(2-ethylhexyl)terephthalate (DOTP). In addition, MIL-125 also showed excellent catalytic performance for the syntheses of other plasticizers (DOP, TOTM, DOA and DOS). The control experiments demonstrated that the titanium metal nodes of the MOFs dominate this kind of esterification reaction while functional groups on the ligands and structural defects give a certain positive effect. MIL-125 has been proved to be a heterogeneous catalyst with high efficiency and good recyclability, mitigating the pollution and promising for economic and environmental friendliness in the practical production of traditional plasticizers. Keywords Metal−organic frameworks Heterogeneous catalyst Esterification Plasticizers Recyclability 1 Introduction Plasticizers have attracted great concerns due to their excellent performance in improving the properties of plastics for applications ranging from the automotive industry to medical products [1–3]. Ester type plasticizers are currently the most commonly used ones because of the striking improvement of the cold fracture performance for traditional plastics, e.g. plasticized poly(vinyl chloride) [4]. As a kind of environmental friendly ester plasticizer, millions of tons of di-(2-ethylhexyl)terephthalate (DOTP) is desperately demanded all over the world every year in view of its superior performance in both physical and mechanical enhancements of various plastics [5]. DOTP could be synthesized by chlorination of carboxylic acid, transesterification or esterification reaction [6,7]. Given the economic and environmental concerns, esterification of aromatic carboxylic acids is now the optimal strategy for synthesis of DOTP, of which the synthesis is generally catalyzed by strong acids or Ti(OPr)4 with reaction temperature higher than 200 °C. Although the strong acids and inorganic melt salts have been widely applied as catalysts in practical production due to their low price and affordability, immense amounts of lye and water are concurrently needed to neutralize the strong acid and remove the harmful residual catalyst in the work-up procedures, inevitably resulting in the corrosion of equipment, severe environmental issues and high production cost. In addition, the homogenous catalysts undoubtedly lead to complex separation procedures and decrease the quality of the products by catalyst residue, whereas the plastic materials used overwhelmingly in our daily life are essentially demanded without life-detrimental contamination. Compared with the homogenous catalysts, the outstanding advantages of heterogeneous catalysts are that they can be isolated from the reaction system by simple filtration and recycled for many times, thus avoiding the problems from homogeneous reactions. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop novel highly efficient heterogeneous catalytic systems for the syntheses of plasticizers. In the past three decades, metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) composed by organic linkers and metal nodes, are emerging as a new class of porous crystalline materials which have attracted considerable interests due to their fascinating architectures and versatile applications [8–15]. One of the vital interests in MOF applications is originated from the structural diversity, defects, abundant Lewis acid sites and heterogeneity as efficient and green catalysts [16–18]. Owing to their high porosity, large surface area, designable frameworks and facile surface functionalization, MOFs have been extensively applied as sustainable heterogeneous catalysts such as Knoevenagel condensation, oxidation and esterification, featuring superior catalytic activity and stability [19–25]. For example, Kaskel et al. synthesized DUT-67(Zr/Hf)-HCl by anion exchange with diluted hydrochloric acid in order to improve the catalytic properties. Compared with the pristine DUT-67, the turnover frequency (TOF) of DUT-67-HCl shows ca. 18-fold increase in the esterification of levulinic acid (LA) for Zr-based MOFs and 50-fold increase for the Hf-based MOFs [26]. Guo et al. fabricated Cu-BTC-HPM by post-synthetic modification of HKUST-1 [Cu3(BTC)2, BTC = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate], i.e., loading phosphomolybdic acid (HPM) within the pores of HKUST-1. The Cu-BTC-HPM was used for the esterification of LA with ethanol, and afforded 92.4 % yield while no conversion was observed catalyzed by parent HKUST-1 [27]. These researches proved that esterification performances of the MOF catalysts depend on the acid modification, which would result in acid pollution to some extent. Yılmaz et al. synthesized non-acid functionalized MIL-125 [(Ti8O8(OH)4(BDC)6, BDC = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, Fig. 1 a] and employed it for esteriﬁcation of acetic acid (AC), giving only 78.5 % conversion [28]. Albeit intensive researches suggest the high potential to utilize MOFs as heterogeneous catalysts applying for esterification of various substrates, to the best of our knowledge, systematic and comprehensive studies on the MOFs for catalyzing traditional plasticizer synthesis to address the current manufacturing issues have not been reported yet. More importantly, the massive production of various MOFs has been gradually addressed, making most of the traditional MOFs cost-effective and commercially available [29–31]. And the tremendous input in the basic research of the MOFs in the past three decades has urgently demanded to find their practical applications [32–35]. Herein, we synthesized a series of MOFs, i.e., MIL-125, MIL-125-NH2, UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, UiO-66-SO3H and MIL-101, and employed them as heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of traditional plasticizer DOTP. Among all these MOFs, MIL-125 not only exhibits the best catalytic activity but also gives good recyclability under the optimal reaction condition screened out. In addition, dioctyl phthalate (DOP), dioctyl sebacate (DOS), dioctyl adipic (DOA), trioctyl trimellitate (TOTM) as the major important plasticizers could also be readily synthesized by heterogeneously catalytic reaction with MIL-125. The catalytic mechanism was proposed that the Ti nodes of MIL-125 as Lewis acid sites govern these esterification reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All chemicals for synthesis were commercially available analytical grade reagents and used without further purification. Tetrabutyl titanate was stored and used in glove box for isolation of air and H2O. The nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements were conducted on Bruker AV600 spectrometer (600 MHz for 1H). Chemical shifts (δ) are given with reference to 1H NMR chemical shifts of the DMSO-d 6 (1H (δ) = 2.5). The absolute values of the coupling constants are given in Hertz (Hz). Powder X–ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were obtained using a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker AXS Inc. Madison, WI, 2001) (Cu Kα, λ = 0.15418 nm) in a 2θ range of 5 − 40° under ambient temperature at 45 kV and 40 mA, using a step size of 0.01°. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) instrument (S−4800, Hitachi, Japan) linked to an Oxford Instruments X−ray analysis system. The Ti4+ concentration in the reaction mixture was analyzed by an inductively coupled plasma−optical emission spectroscopy (ICP−OES, PerkinElmer Optima 8300). 2.2 Preparation and characterization of MOFs MIL-125 [36], MIL-125-NH2 [37], UiO-66 [38], UiO-66-B [39], UiO-66-C [40], UiO-66-NH2 [41], UiO-66-SO3H [42,43], MIL-101 [44] were prepared by slightly modified methods according to the reported procedures in the literatures. All these MOFs have been intensively studied in structures as well as the essential physicochemical properties. And thus only the details of MOF structures are displayed in Fig. 1, respectively. As intuitively shown in Fig. 1, the isostructural MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 possess potential Lewis acid metal node Ti8O8(OH)4, while UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH2 manifest Zr6O4(OH)4 as potential Lewis acid node. And UiO-66-SO3H and MIL-101 have Zr and Cr metal nodes, respectively. To verify the success of MOF syntheses, the PXRD of the as-synthesized MOFs has been conducted carefully. The PXRD profiles of the experimental data are consistent very well with the simulated patterns from the single crystal XRD (Fig. S1), indicating the high phase purity and the successful preparation of all the above MOFs. 2.3 General procedures of catalytic investigations 2.3.1 General procedure for screening the optimal reaction condition BDC (0.040 mmol, 6.6 mg), MIL-125 (varied 1.0 mol% ∼ 4.0 mol%, 0.5 mg ∼ 2.2 mg) and 2-ethyl-1-hexanol (EH) (varied 1.0 ∼ 5.0 equiv, 10.4 mg ∼ 52.1 mg) were added in an NMR tube. The NMR tube was treated with ultrasound for 3.0 min. Then the mixture was heated at a given reaction temperature. After reaction, the reaction mixture was dissolved in DMSO-d 6 and checked by 1H NMR spectra. In addition, the yield of the product was calculated according to the integration of 1H NMR spectra by the following equation: Y ield = ( 1 ‒ Integration of the BDC Integration of the BDC + Integration of the DOTP ) × 100% Taking the calculation of the DOTP yield as an example, the 1H NMR spectra of the mixtures before (Fig. 2 a) and after reaction (Fig. 2b) are shown in Fig. 2 respectively. The characteristic 1H NMR chemical shifts for aromatic protons have been assigned at 8.07 ppm for DOTP and 8.04 ppm for BDC (Fig. 2a). The 1H NMR chemical shifts of mono-(2-ethylhexyl)terephthalate were assigned to 8.13 ppm and 8.19 ppm in Fig. S8,and obviously there is no mono-substituted product mono-(2-ethylhexyl)terephthalate which was observed in the spectrum after the reaction initiated (Fig. 2b). Following the above equation, the yields of the DOTP product can be readily calculated out by using the integrations of the peaks for BDC (8.04 ppm) and DOTP (8.07 ppm). As shown in Fig. 2b, with the DOTP yield of this reaction gradually increasing and finally reaching 99.9 %, the peak at 8.04 ppm decreased accordingly and disappeared after the reaction. 2.3.2 General procedure under the optimal reaction condition Carboxylic acid (BDC, Phthalic acid, Trimellitic acid, Adipic acid and Decanedioic acid, 0.040 mmol, 6.6 mg), MOFs (1.0 mol%, 0.5 mg) and EH alcohol (0.40 mmol, 52.1 mg) were added in an NMR tube and treated with ultrasound for 1.0 min. Then the mixture was heated at 190 °C for 1.0 h. After reaction, 0.40 mL of DMSO-d 6 was added and the mixture was checked by 1H NMR spectra on Bruker AV600 spectrometer. 2.3.3 General procedure for the kinetic experiments and hot filtration experiments Kinetic experiments: BDC (4.0 mmol, 0.7 g), EH (40 mmol, 5.2 g) and MIL-125 (0.20 mol%, 11.0 mg) were mixed in a two-necked, round-bottom flask. The reaction was carried out at 190 °C under gentle reflux in 8.0 h and the conversions were monitored by 1H NMR spectra in every 0.50 or 1.0 h. Hot filtration experiments: BDC (1.0 mmol, 0.17 g), EH (10 mmol, 1.3 g) and MIL-125 (0.20 mol%, 2.8 mg) were mixed in glass tube. The reactions were allowed to proceed at 190 °C under gentle reflux in 2.0 h. After 1.0 h the heterogeneous particles was removed immediately from the hot reaction mixture by centrifugation. According to the 1H NMR spectra of the reaction solution after centrifugation, 0.10 g of fresh BDC was added to make up for the loss of centrifugation. The reaction mixture was heated to 190 °C under gentle reflux again and the conversions were monitored by 1H NMR spectra. 2.3.4 General procedure for ICP test BDC (4.0 mmol, 0.7 g), EH (40 mmol, 5.2 g) and MIL-125 (1.0 mol%, 55.0 mg) were mixed in a two-necked round-bottom flask. The reaction was carried out at 190 °C under gentle reflux in 6.0 h. And then the reaction mixture was centrifuged. The supernatant fraction was digested by heating at 150 °C in 1.0 mL of aqua regia (VHCl: VH2SO4 = 3 : 1) for 20 min. To the resultant clear solution, 1.0 mL of deionized H2O was added for dilution. The Ti content of the diluted solution was analyzed by ICP measurements. 2.3.5 General procedure for the recyclability of MIL-125 as catalyst Recycling reaction was performed in a tube with gentle stirring. BDC (4.0 mmol, 0.7 g), EH (40 mmol, 5.2 g) and MIL-125 (1.0 mol%, 55.0 mg) were mixed and heated at 190 °C under gentle reflux for 1.0 h. After the reaction, 2.0 mL of DMSO-d 6 was added to the mixture and subsequently separated by centrifugation. The liquid phase was used for examination of the yields by 1H NMR measurements; the catalyst was collected and washed with DMF and EtOH for several times, and carefully dried under vacuum for directly using in the next cycling reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of the reaction conditions In practical, the classic plasticizer DOTP is generally synthesized by esterification reaction of BDC (1, 4-dicarboxybenzene) and EH (2-ethyl-1-hexanol). Initially, the optimized condition was screened out by the model reaction of the DOTP synthesis catalyzed by MIL-125 MOF. The reaction temperature, the amount of EH alcohol and MIL-125 are the most important factors for the esterification. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the yield was only 40.0 % when the reaction temperature was 160 °C. As the temperature was elevated to 190 °C the yield increased to 93.5 %, indicating higher reaction temperature will significantly accelerate the reaction speed, i.e., larger kinetic constants [45]. Concurrently, control experiments were carried out under the same condition except for the absence of MIL-125 and showed that almost no conversion was observed without catalyst even at 190 °C. The EH amount to this reaction is also of great significance in view of that it serves not only as reactant but also solvent. As shown in Fig. 3b, as the amount of EH increased, the reaction yield was distinctly improved and achieved 99.9 % yield with 4.0 equiv of EH. It is notable that the reactants of this reaction are heterogeneous due to the very low solubility of BDC in EH, and thus increasing the amount of EH results in larger quantity of BDC in the reaction solution, leading to the dramatic improvement of DOTP yield. To gain deeper insight into the impact on the three factors, the conversions of the DOTP were plotted against the amount of MIL-125 catalyst under different temperatures and times (Fig. 4 ). It was found that increasing the amount of MIL-125 to 4.0 mol% led to a certain improvement at 180 °C yet complete conversion could not be achieved. With the reaction temperature elevating to 190 °C, the DOTP yield could be increased to 99.9 % in 0.50 h via dosing the MIL-125 catalyst amount to 3.0 mol%, while under 190 °C in 1.0 h the reactions afforded quantitative yield even only with 1.0 mol% catalyst, indicating the critical factor of reaction temperature (Fig. 4). Therefore, the optimal reaction condition was screened out that in the presence of 1.0 mol% MIL-125, 1.0 equiv BDC reacted with 5.0 equiv EH at 190 °C for 1.0 h. 3.2 Catalytic performance of different MOFs in synthesis of DOTP Encouraged by these primary results, we attempted to explore other MOFs possessing high potential for superior efficiency and verify the key factors, i.e., unsaturated metal sites (UMSs), organic catalytic sites (OCSs) and structural defects. Recently Zr-based MOFs such as UiO-66 have been proved to show efficient catalytic performance based on the UMSs as Lewis acid sites and excellent stability [46–50]. And defects and OCSs such as −SO3H and −NH2 on the pore surface of the MOFs have been demonstrated to exert great effects on the catalytic esterification reactions [51–53]. Therefore, a series of promising MOFs with potential UMSs/OCSs, UiO-66, UiO-66-B, UiO-66-C, UiO-66-SO3H, UiO-66-NH2, MIL-101, MIL-125-NH2 were synthesized accordingly for catalytic synthesis of DOTP under the optimal reaction condition. To verify whether the esterification reaction occurs inside the pores, UiO-66 MOFs with different particle sizes, i.e., UiO-66, UiO-66-B, UiO-66-C were prepared by addition of the modulators. As estimated from the SEM images in Fig. S2, UiO-66 (without modulator), UiO-66-B (benzoic acid as modulator) and UiO-66-C (acetic acid as modulator) could be successfully synthesized in the size of ca. 40 nm, 300 nm and 1 μm respectively (for the details see SI). However, utilization of UiO-66, UiO-66-B or UiO-66-C as catalyst led to comparable catalytic reaction yields of 10.7 %, 9.4 % and 10.4 % respectively (Table 1 , Entries 1 − 3) indicating that the catalytic esterification took place not only on the surface but also in the pores. Compared with the UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2 bearing the same Zr UMSs but additional −NH2 OCSs (Fig. 1d) exhibited improved yield of 16.1 % while the unique UiO-66-SO3H MOF possessing Zr UMSs (Fig. 1e), three dimensionally ordered defect and −SO3H OCSs further accelerate the conversion to 17.2 % (Table 1, Entries 1, 4 − 5). Although the defects and functionalized OCSs of the MOFs are considered to have some improvement for the efficiency, the yields are less than satisfactory, which may be attributed to the anhydrous condition of these catalytic systems, corroborated by Caratelli et al. [19]. Additionally, MIL-101 with potential Cr UMSs (Fig. 1f) was found to be inactive to this esterification reaction with negligible conversion probably due to the low Lewis acidity (Entry 6). The MIL-125-NH2 exhibited the same high efficiency (99.9 % yield) as MIL-125, however the ligand 2-aminoterephthalic acid is far more expensive than the ligand BDC (Entries 7 − 8). Commercially available inorganic catalyst Zn(CH3COO)2 and organic catalyst p-C7H8SO3H were also subjected to this catalytic reaction but only negligible and 5.6 % yields were achieved, respectively (Entries 9 − 10). In order to further compare the catalytic activity, the turnover frequencies (TOF) were calculated under the optimal reaction condition. The TOF value was calculated to be 99.9 h−1 (Entries 7 − 8) for MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2, which is almost ten times of UiO-66 and the largest among all the tested MOF materials hypothesizing each metal node of the MOF has one available catalytic site on average (Entries 1 − 8). The catalytic performance such as conversions and TOF values for esterification reactions over various catalysts were summarized in Table S1 for comparison. The high TOF value further verified the high catalytic activity of MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 in the catalytic EH esterification of BDC. These control experiments of different MOFs distinctly suggested that the Ti UMSs of the MOFs readily generating under this high reaction temperature are the key factor to succeed in this highly efficient esterification, suppressing the other factors. It is notable that the porosity nature of the MOFs making the Ti UMSs accessible is certainly significant, which was elucidated by comparison with the heterogeneous catalysis using the nonporous TiO2 catalyst. The reaction with TiO2 under the same condition gave negligible conversion even though the amount increased to 8.0 mol% (Entry 11). Moreover, in practical industry the DOTP was manufactured via homogeneous reaction catalyzed by Ti(OPr)4. For comparison, the reactions using Ti(OPr)4 catalyst under the same condition were also examined. As the amount of Ti(OPr)4 increased to 4.0 mol%, a complete conversion of the DOTP could be achieved (Entries 12 − 13), and thus the TOF value of MIL-125 is more than three times of that catalyzed by Ti(OPr)4. Above all, the high efficiency of this heterogeneous MIL-125 catalyst for DOTP synthesis is attributed to the accessible Ti nodes as UMSs although the Brønsted acid or base groups will promote the esterification to some extent. 3.3 Catalytic ability of MIL-125 for syntheses of traditional plasticizers The MIL-125 catalytic system was successfully applied in the syntheses of other typical plasticizers based on the optimized condition. As shown in Table 2 , the current ester type plasticizers mainly manufactured in industry (i.e., DOP, DOS, DOA and TOTM) could be synthesized in 99.9 % yield (Entries 1 − 4) [54–56]. Notably the substrates tolerant of this highly efficient catalytic system varied from dicarboxylic acid to tricarboxylic acid, and aromatic carboxylic acid to alkyl carboxylic acid with different chain lengths. However, reaction of BDC with octyl alcohol catalyzed by MIL-125 afforded 45.3 % yield, while a modest improvement of the yield was obtained by MIL-125-NH2 catalyst, indicating a positive effect provided by the −NH2 group which as Brønsted base sites may synergize with Ti UMSs to facilitate the esterification (Entries 5 − 6). 3.4 Heterogeneity of MIL-125 To reveal the heterogeneous characteristic of this catalytic system, the hot filtration experiment was conducted by removing the solid MIL-125 catalyst after reaction for 1.0 h. As shown in Fig. 5 , 0.20 mol% of MIL-125 was used to slow down the reaction and the conversion of the reaction remained constant after the hot filtration, while the control experiment continued to proceed to give 59.7 % yield in 2.0 h, evidencing the heterogeneity of this catalytic system (Fig. 5). 3.5 Recyclability of MIL-125 catalyst In the use of MOF catalysts, the crucial advantage compared with homogeneous catalysts is the ability of easy separation from the reaction solution and good recyclability. Thus, recovery experiments of catalyst MIL-125 were conducted, showing negligible decrease of the product yield in the second cycle. Although a slight decrease in the catalyst performance was shown after every cycle, 65.2 % yield still remained in the eighth run (Fig. 6 a). The PXRD patterns of the recycled catalysts revealed that the catalyst MIL-125 could retain its original high crystalline structure without noticeable degradation (Fig. 6b). The SEM images revealed the MIL-125 pellet crystals have been partially smashed into smaller particles (Fig. S9). Accordingly, the center of the estimated size distribution decreased from 1.66 μm to 0.66 μm after the fourth cycle (Fig. S10), which may be resulted from the gentle reflux or stirring during the reactions [57–59]. On the other hand, ICP−OES was used to analyze the elemental content of Ti after the heterogeneous catalytic reaction at 190 °C for 6.0 h in order to evaluate the framework stability of MIL-125. Only 0.21 wt% of Ti (5.2 ppm) leaching from the catalyst was detected by the reaction mixture, indicating the good stability of MIL-125 in this catalytic system. In particular, BDC and Ti4+ are the degradation products of MIL-125, both of which play a role in synthesizing DOTP, that are, BDC would be converted to DOTP and residual Ti4+ can be the homogeneous catalyst to promote the reaction. In the practical industrial production, millions of tons of DOTP was generally produced by homogeneous reaction of BDC with EH alcohol catalyzed by Ti(IV) butoxide, encountering an intractable problem of completely removing the detrimental Ti residual. Huge amount of water and some kinds of base were consumed by copious washing, therefore resulting in a mass of industrial wastewater with severe environmental issues. Inspired by the above experimental results and elucidation, one more step to pre-prepare MIL-125 from the homogeneous catalyst Ti(IV) butoxide and reactant BDC and subsequent using it for the heterogeneous DOTP synthesis will endow the present catalytic system with economic and environmental friendly, i.e., simple filtration to remove the Ti(IV) catalyst and recycling to reduce the cost and energy consumption. 3.6 Determination of the kinetic rate constant To preliminarily evaluate the performance of the catalyst kinetics experiments were carried out in order to briefly determine the kinetic rate constant. With the optimized condition the reaction is very efficient to accomplish in 1.0 h. Therefore, to estimate the value more accurately the reaction was slightly slowed down by decreasing the catalyst amount to 0.20 mol% resulting in accomplishment of the reaction in 6.0 h (Fig. S11). According to 1H NMR spectra of the reactions in Fig. 2 and Fig. S8, no obvious signal of the monosubstituted product mono-(2-ethylhexyl)terephthalate could be found in 1H NMR spectra, suggesting the process of producing monosubstituted intermediate is the rate-determining step [60,61]. Because the reactant EH alcohol as a solvent is much excessive, the whole reaction can be simplified as a pseudo-first order reaction. Indeed, as shown in Fig. S11 the experimental data fitted very well with the pseudo-first order kinetic rate model (correlation coefficient R 2 = 0.995). And the calculated kinetic rate constant k′ is 0.49 h−1 (see SI for details), relatively higher than that of other reported MOF catalyzed esterification, e.g., the k′ value of UiO-66-NH2 catalyzed esterification of levulinic acid (LA) varied from 0.33 h−1 to 0.43 h−1 [61]. 3.7 Plausible mechanistic consideration on MIL-125 catalysis of esterification It is notable that by screening a series of MOFs with different metal nodes or the same metal node but different ligand substituents, the metal nodes of the MOFs with Lewis acid characteristic were found to be the critical factor governing the catalytic performance of this esterification for plasticizers. The amine base on the ligands of the Zr node MOF (UiO-66-NH2) was proved to cooperatively facilitate the esterification of LA. As the same group element, the Ti node in MIL-125-NH2 synergizing with amine groups showed enhanced efficiency for the esterification, but without the amine groups the Ti oxo-clusters in MIL-125 provided sufficient Lewis acidity for efficient catalysis of these esterification reactions of various plasticizers. It is also worth mentioning that the high reaction temperature is critical for complete activation of the Ti UMSs and distinct from other catalytic esterification because of the high boiling points of the reactants for plasticizer syntheses. Based on the previous researches and our experimental results [62–65], the reaction mechanism of MIL-125 catalyzed esterification is rationally proposed in Fig. 7 . First, carbonyl group of carboxylic acid coordinates onto the active Lewis acid sites of Ti oxo-clusters in MIL-125 (i.e., unsaturated Ti site, activated under the high reaction temperature) to further polarize the carbonyl group, facilitating the nucleophilic attack by the alcohol molecule. And then the intramolecular proton shift followed by the water molecule cleave leads to coordinated ester. Finally, coordination substitution of another carboxylic acid releases the produced coordinated ester to initiate the next catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of MOFs (MIL-101, MIL-125, MIL-125-NH2, UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, and UiO-66-SO3H) have been employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of DOTP, but only MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 manifest prominent efficiency while other MOFs give low yields and heterogeneous TiO2 shows barely catalytic performance. The MIL-125 could also be applied for catalytic esterification to synthesize other plasticizers, i.e., DOP, TOTM, DOA and DOS, with quantitative conversions in 1.0 h under 190 °C. In addition, investigation on the heterogeneous reactions catalyzed by MIL-125 gave a high TOF of 99.9 h−1, large kinetic rate constant of 0.49 h−1 and good recyclability of 65.2 % yield after eight consecutive runs. Deeper insight into the mechanism demonstrated that the Ti nodes of MIL-125 as catalytic Lewis acid sites govern the efficient esterification reaction which could be further boosted by synergism with the basic amine groups of MIL-125-NH2. We envision that this research will provide inspiration to exploit versatile MOFs as heterogeneous catalysts for the economic and environment-benign production of significant bulk fine chemicals in industry. coredata.dc:description: Practically the traditional plasticizers are produced via homogeneous esterification reaction in millions of tons annually as additives for modulating the properties of polymeric materials, facing great environment pressure such as a huge amount of wastewater produced to remove the detrimental metal catalyst. In this work, a series of MOFs, MIL-101, MIL-125, MIL-125-NH2, UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, and UiO-66-SO3H, have been synthesized and employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the syntheses of plasticizers. MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2 were found to show the superior catalytic efficiency compared with other MOFs. Catalyzed by only 1.0 mol% of MIL-125 within 1.0 h at 190 °C, the heterogeneous reaction achieved 99.9 % yield of Di-(2-ethylhexyl)terephthalate (DOTP). In addition, MIL-125 also showed excellent catalytic performance for the syntheses of other plasticizers (DOP, TOTM, DOA and DOS). The control experiments demonstrated that the titanium metal nodes of the MOFs dominate this kind of esterification reaction while functional groups on the ligands and structural defects give a certain positive effect. MIL-125 has been proved to be a heterogeneous catalyst with high efficiency and good recyclability, mitigating the pollution and promising for economic and environmental friendliness in the practical production of traditional plasticizers.
coredata.dc:title: Metal−organic frameworks as recyclable catalysts for efficient esterification to synthesize traditional plasticizers
